entries.title: Mastering Table Tennis Grips: Shakehand vs. Penhold – Which Is Right for You?
entries.summary: Compares the two primary grips, explains how to hold each correctly, pros/cons, common errors, and simple grip-control drills.

how_to: Hold the handle like a handshake; handle sits in palm.
Index finger rests slightly along the backhand rubber edge (not too far).
Thumb rests lightly on the opposite side of the handle.
Keep the grip relaxed for flexibility and control.
advantages: Excellent reach and range of motion.
common_mistakes: Squeezing too tightly → reduced wrist mobility.
Index finger extended too far onto rubber → limits backhand control.
Locked wrist → less variation and feel.

how_to: Pinch the handle with thumb and index finger like a pen.
Rest remaining fingers on the back of the blade.
Keep wrist loose to maximize spin and dexterity.
advantages: Enhanced wrist mobility for quick spin/flicks.
common_mistakes: Overreliance on forehand; neglecting backhand development.
Holding too low on the handle → less control.

entries.which_grip_guidance: Choose Shakehand for a balanced two-wing game; choose Penhold for wrist-driven, close-to-table attacking. Trial both in practice.
drills: Shadow strokes in front of a mirror to check hand position.
Ball control: bounce a ball on the racket for 30 seconds with each grip, varying spin and height.

entries.title: The Rules of Table Tennis (Quick Reference)
entries.summary: Plain-English overview of scoring, match format, equipment specs, service/return, doubles, and common FAQs.

scoring.game: First to 11, must win by 2 if 10–10.
scoring.match: Best of an odd number of games (e.g., 1, 3, 5, or 7).
scoring.service_rotation: Serve changes every 2 points; at 10–10 it alternates every point.

equipment.table: 2.74 m x 1.525 m; height 76 cm; sides are NOT part of the playing surface.
equipment.racket: Any size/shape; one side bright red, other a contrasting color.

good_service_requirements: Ball rests freely on open, stationary palm behind end line and above the playing surface.
Toss near-vertically at least 16 cm with no spin.
Ball must first bounce on server’s court, then over/around net to receiver’s court.
Ball must be visible to receiver throughout.
service.good_return: Ball passes over/around net and lands on opponent’s court (directly or via net).

doubles.serve_path: From server’s right half-court to receiver’s right half-court.
doubles.order: All players alternate hits; order changes at each service change and when ends change at 5 in the decider.

points_awarded_if: Opponent fails to make a good service or good return.
Ball touches anything other than the net before opponent hits it.
Opponent moves the table or their free hand touches the playing surface.
In doubles, opponent plays out of sequence.

common_questions.a: The white top line is IN; the side of the tabletop is OUT.

common_questions.q: How many lets can you serve?
common_questions.a: Unlimited; lets never lose a point.

common_questions.q: Can you lean or touch the table?
common_questions.a: Your bat and body can touch; your NON-playing hand cannot touch the surface.
Over the table = you lose the point; after the ball passes the end line = you win the point.

entries.title: Progress Isn’t Linear
entries.summary: Improvement comes with ups, downs, plateaus, and occasional regressions—similar to a plant growing unseen roots before new growth.
key_points: Skill upgrades often feel worse before they feel better.
Reframe setbacks as data for the next leap.
reflection_prompts: What can I learn from today’s struggles?
Is there a technical flaw to address?
Do I need a mental shift (focus, confidence, routines)?

entries.title: Why Young Athletes Should Play Many Sports: Specialisation vs Generalisation
entries.summary: Generalising in youth builds broader physical literacy, reduces injury risk, maintains motivation, and supports long-term success.
case_for_generalisation: Develops coordination, balance, strength, adaptability, decision-making.
Reduces overuse injuries via varied movement patterns.
Keeps sport fun; lowers burnout risk.
risks_of_early_specialisation: Higher overuse injury risk in developing bodies.
guidance_for_parents_coaches: Encourage exploration of multiple sports in childhood.
Aim for long-term love of activity over early wins.
Let the athlete gravitate naturally when ready.

entries.title: The Secret to Consistency and Power: Table Tennis Footwork Explained
entries.summary: Footwork underpins balance, positioning, consistency, and power; elite players cover meters per rally by staying poised and efficient.
why_footwork_matters: Right position = cleaner timing, higher consistency.
Balanced base enables power (especially forehand loop).

common_challenges_and_fixes.fix: Shadow drills with slight forward lean; stay on balls of the feet.

common_challenges_and_fixes.issue: Reaching with arm instead of moving
common_challenges_and_fixes.fix: Lead with feet; side-to-side shadow with integrated swings.
Random placement drills emphasizing recover-to-balance after each shot.

drills: Side-to-side shadow movement (3×1-min sets; add racket swings).
Two-point forehand (BH corner → FH corner loops; 10–15 reps per set).
Random placement (coach/robot unpredictable feeds; recover to neutral each shot).
habits: Warm up 5–10 minutes with footwork before strokes.
During matches, consciously reset to a balanced stance after each shot.
Track weekly success in random drills to measure progress.

entries.title: From Beginner to Advanced: The Roadmap to Table Tennis Mastery
entries.summary: Seven-stage progression: strokes → linking → randomisation → serve/return → match drills → match play → psychology.

stages.name: Basic Strokes
stages.key_drill: Hit 100 FH and 100 BH drives consecutively.

stages.name: Linking Strokes
stages.key_drill: Alternate FH/BH continuously to build rhythm.

stages.name: Randomisation
stages.key_drill: Add 1 random ball per pattern, increase randomness over time.

stages.name: Serve & Return
stages.key_drill: Short/long serve variations followed by specific receive patterns.

stages.name: Match Drills
stages.key_drill: Set-patterns: serve → third ball → rally → finish.

stages.name: Match Play
stages.key_drill: Regular matches with targeted strategic objectives.

entries.title: Topspin Explained: The Science Behind the Spin
entries.summary: Defines topspin, why it matters, how to generate it, Magnus effect, key strokes, and practice guidance.
why_topspin: Lets you hit harder with control (dip/clear net/land safely).
Produces balls that are harder to counter cleanly.
mechanics: Upward brushing contact with a slightly closed racket.
Prioritise spin creation first, then add power.
Contact in an upward arc to roll the ball over the rubber.
entries.magnus_effect: Forward rotation lowers pressure beneath the ball, creating a downward ‘dip’ that pulls the ball onto the table.
key_strokes: Forehand topspin to initiate or finish.
Topspin vs heavy backspin (lift to convert defense to offense).
practice: Slow brush-focused rallies; increase speed gradually.
Multiball sequences for rhythm and repetition.
common_mistakes: Open racket angle causing balls to fly long.
advanced_tips: Fine-tune racket angle for spin vs speed trade-offs.
Use topspin for both attack and resilient defense.
Adapt spin amount/trajectory to opponent’s style and spin input.

entries.title: Breaking Through a Slump: A Guide for Table Tennis Players
entries.summary: Slumps are normal; analyse, reset fundamentals, vary training, set short-term goals, rest, and strengthen the mental game.

methods: Identify stroke, footwork, timing, or mental blockers
Slow, precise drills to restore clean mechanics
Short break to reduce mental/physical fatigue

entries.title: Developing a Killer Serve in Table Tennis
entries.summary: Build a high-pressure serve system with spin mastery, deception, varied placement/speed, pressure practice, and in-match adaptation.

pillars.name: Master the basics
points: Accurate placement to all zones (short/long, body, wide).
Reliable spin creation (top, back, side) via brush contact.

pillars.name: Spin variety
points: Heavy backspin to force pushes (see: ‘Ma Lin Ghost Serve’ concept).
Topspin to provoke higher, quicker returns for 3rd-ball attack.
Sidespin for curve and misreads; blend spins for subtlety.

pillars.name: Deception
points: Use similar arm/bat motion across different spins.
Include no-spin (float) options to bait over-reads.
Hide spin change in contact, not in the wind-up.

pillars.name: Placement & speed
points: Mix short-double-bounce (~80%) with surprise long-fast (~20%) serves.
Target wide FH/BH and into the body to jam timing.

pillars.name: Practice under pressure
points: Start games at 9–9 to rehearse clutch execution.

pillars.name: Adapt during matches
points: Repeat what hurts the opponent until they adjust.
When read, switch length/spin/placement to reset uncertainty.

match_checklist: Do my short serves bounce twice if untouched?
Am I using the same motion for different spins?
Have I served to all three lanes (wide FH, body, wide BH)?
What’s my most effective serve today—am I using it enough?
